questions.question: What is Data Structures?
options: A type of computer processor.
A file format used for saving data.
A programming language used in web development.
A way to organize and store data efficiently.
questions.correctAnswer: A way to organize and store data efficiently.

questions.question: Why do we need data structures?
options: To manage data efficiently and improve performance.
To make computers run slower.
To delete unnecessary files
To increase storage space on a hard drive.
questions.correctAnswer: To manage data efficiently and improve performance.

questions.question: Which data structure follows LIFO (Last In, First Out)?
options: Queue
Stack
Linked List
Tree

questions.question: What data structure follows FIFO (First In, First Out)?
options: Queue
Stack
Linked List
Tree

questions.question: A ______ organizes and stores data in a structured way.
An ______ stores multiple elements in a fixed order.
A ______ is used to map unique keys to specific values for quick retrieval.
What happens if data is not organized properly in a program?
options: Searching and processing data becomes slow and inefficient.
The computer ignores unorganized data.
The program automatically arranges the data.
Data structures will fix themselves over time.
questions.correctAnswer: Searching and processing data becomes slow and inefficient.

questions.question: What is an algorithm?
options: A step-by-step process for solving a problem.
A type of software for designing UI.
A function used only for sorting data.
A computer hardware component.
questions.correctAnswer: A step-by-step process for solving a problem.

questions.question: Why do computers need algorithms?
options: To perform tasks efficiently by following a logical sequence.
To slow down processing speed for security reasons.
To store large amounts of data without organizing it.
To make random decisions without human input.
questions.correctAnswer: To perform tasks efficiently by following a logical sequence.

questions.question: What does Big-O Notation measure?
options: The weight of data stored in memory.
The maximum file size an algorithm can process
The number of variables used in a program.
The number of programming languages an algorithm supports.
questions.correctAnswer: The time and space efficiency of an algorithm.

questions.question: A ______ is used to describe an algorithm’s efficiency.
options: It takes more time and resources to complete a task.
The weight of data stored in memory.
The maximum file size an algorithm can process.
The number of variables used in a program.
questions.correctAnswer: It takes more time and resources to complete a task.

questions.question: What happens when you reverse (DOG)?
Which sorting algorithm works by repeatedly swapping adjacent elements?
Searching for an item in an organized list is ______ than searching randomly.
What is a string?
options: A sequence of characters
A type of number
A mathematical equation
A function

questions.question: Why do computers need strings?
options: To store and process text
To perform calculations
To execute functions
To store only numbers

questions.question: What is ASCII used for?
options: Encoding text into numerical values
Solving mathematical equations
Executing JavaScript code
Running computer programs

questions.question: The function to remove spaces at the beginning and end of a string is ______.
How do you make text lowercase in Java?
options: toLowerCase()
toUpperCase()
trim()
split()

questions.question: What’s the ASCII code for 'A'?
What happens when you reverse 'dog'?
Computers store text using ______ encoding.
What is an array?
options: A collection of elements stored in a fixed order.
A function that repeats indefinitely.
A random collection of data that changes order.
A file format for saving text documents.
A tool for measuring distances in programming.
questions.correctAnswer: A collection of elements stored in a fixed order.

questions.question: How does a record differ from an array?
options: A record can store multiple data types, while an array stores a single type.
A record can only store numbers, while an array stores only text.
Arrays store data with named fields, while records use index positions.
Records are faster than arrays in all cases.
Arrays are always larger than records.
questions.correctAnswer: A record can store multiple data types, while an array stores a single type.

questions.question: A ______ holds multiple elements of the same type.
A ______ stores a group of related data with different types.
A ______ points to a memory location.
What is a pointer used for?
options: Storing the memory address of another variable.
Sorting a list of numbers in ascending order.
Increasing computer speed.
Organizing data in an array.
Printing text in a document.
questions.correctAnswer: Storing the memory address of another variable.

questions.question: What does a pointer reference?
Which data type is used for storing multiple records of student names and grades?
How does a linked list store data?
options: It stores data in nodes, each linking to the next node.
It stores all data in a single continuous memory block.
It saves data in a compressed format.
It uses only numerical values to represent information.
It arranges data in a table format.
questions.correctAnswer: It stores data in nodes, each linking to the next node.

questions.question: A ______ is the basic unit of a linked list.
The ______ is the first node in a linked list.
Why do programmers use linked lists?
options: Because they allow dynamic memory allocation and efficient insertions/deletions.
Because they consume less memory than arrays in all cases.
Because they make programs slower on purpose.
Because they are easier to sort than arrays.
Because they are the only way to store data in a program.
questions.correctAnswer: Because they allow dynamic memory allocation and efficient insertions/deletions.

questions.question: What does the tail of a linked list point to?
What is an advantage of linked lists over arrays?
Which data structure does NOT use fixed memory allocation?
How do nodes connect in a linked list?
What is a stack?
options: A data structure that follows the Last In, First Out (LIFO) principle.
A structure that removes the first item added.
A type of loop used in programming.
A method for sorting numbers in ascending order.
A type of computer memory that permanently stores data.
questions.correctAnswer: A data structure that follows the Last In, First Out (LIFO) principle.

questions.question: What is a queue?
options: A data structure that follows the First In, First Out (FIFO) principle.
A method for sorting elements from largest to smallest.
A storage system that allows random access to elements.
A structure where the last item added is removed first.
A function that deletes elements in reverse order.
questions.correctAnswer: A data structure that follows the First In, First Out (FIFO) principle.

questions.question: How does recursion work?
options: A function keeps calling itself until it reaches a stopping condition.
A function runs continuously without stopping.
The program executes multiple functions at the same time.
A function stops after a single execution.
Recursion is only used for numerical calculations.
questions.correctAnswer: A function keeps calling itself until it reaches a stopping condition.

questions.question: A ______ data structure is used in undo/redo functions.
A queue follows the ______ principle.
Which data structure is used for waiting lines in banks?
Which of the following is a real-life example of recursion?
options: Russian nesting dolls, where each doll contains a smaller version of itself.
A person standing in a line at a supermarket.
A stack of plates in a cafeteria.
A queue of customers waiting at a bank.
A book placed inside a drawer.
questions.correctAnswer: Russian nesting dolls, where each doll contains a smaller version of itself.

questions.question: Recursion is commonly used in ______ algorithms.
What is a tree in computer science?
options: A hierarchical data structure where each node connects to child nodes.
A type of loop that runs until a condition is met.
A program that generates random numbers.
A method for storing numbers in ascending order.
A mathematical function for sorting values.
questions.correctAnswer: A hierarchical data structure where each node connects to child nodes.

questions.question: What is the topmost node of a tree called?
options: Root Node
Parent Node
Leaf Node
Branch Node
Trunk Node

questions.question: How does a Binary Search Tree (BST) organize elements?
options: Smaller values go to the left subtree, larger values go to the right.
Larger values go to the left subtree, smaller values go to the right.
All values are stored in a straight line.
Elements are stored randomly, with no rules.
The first number is always the largest, and everything follows in descending order.
questions.correctAnswer: Smaller values go to the left subtree, larger values go to the right.

questions.question: Which tree traversal method visits the root node first, then left and right subtrees?
options: Preorder Traversal (Root, Left, Right)
Inorder Traversal (Left, Root, Right)
Postorder Traversal (Left, Right, Root)
Breadth-First Search
Depth-First Search

questions.question: A ______ node has no children.
The ______ is the starting point of a tree.
Why are BSTs more efficient than arrays for searching?
options: Searching is faster because of the sorted structure (O(log n) time complexity).
BSTs use less memory than arrays in all cases.
BSTs automatically delete duplicate values.
BSTs store all data in a single variable.
BSTs are easier to write in every programming language.
questions.correctAnswer: Searching is faster because of the sorted structure (O(log n) time complexity).

questions.question: How do search engines use trees?
options: They organize web pages in a structured hierarchy to improve search efficiency.
They delete unnecessary websites from the internet.
They randomly store search results with no order.
They display search results in alphabetical order only.
They remove duplicate web pages from the internet.
questions.correctAnswer: They organize web pages in a structured hierarchy to improve search efficiency.
